Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	When then it happens to someone else, then hold the edge of the artery with your hand and place the index finger over it: and tighten it very much, until the blood is stopped under your finger, and does not come out of it anything.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then put small olive oil torches on fire, and many in number: and blow over them until they burn well.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take from them one, or small, or big, according to the thickness of the forearm and the place where the artery is broken, and place the torch on it: then remove your finger quickly: and hold the torch, until the blood is cut off.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	That if it is expelled when you take your finger away from the opening of the artery, and put out the torch, then take another torch quickly from the ones that are prepared on fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	So do not stop doing this with one after another, until the blood is cut off.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And beware, so that you do not burn the fire that is there, and happen to bring upon yourself other evil with it.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And you should know that when blood flows from an artery, then it is not possible to stop it: especially if the artery is large, unless with four fingers.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or when with a torch, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or when extracting, when it has not been extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, its ends turn towards the outside, and the blood is cut off.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it is bound with a strong knot of thread.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or are placed on top of the wound by means of its nature, so that the blood is stopped and held with a decreasing constriction.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	But who gives it the cutting and the constricting with thread, and the placing of burning things over it, or similar things, does not give him a complete cut, unless rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	But if it happens to someone else and there is no present doctor or medicine: then let the index finger begin to be placed over the opening of the wound as we have narrated, and the constricting of it very much, until the blood from the upper part of the wound is stopped, and placed on the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger should not be moved away, above it with cold water constantly flowing, until the blood is congealed, and thickens, and is cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And in the meantime, he should consider what needs to be done with the dressing or the medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	[First part of the book].
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	The Book of Surgery of Albucasius Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On incisions, punctures, and bleeding in wounds and similar cases.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already spoken in the first chapter about all sicknesses that are suitable for burning with fire and medicine, their causes, their instruments, their forms of cauterization.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I placed those chapters from the beginning to the end.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I will proceed in this chapter in the same way: so that it may alleviate the questioner's query.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin that, you should learn from your son, that the fear is in the first chapter about cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And for that, you should be cautious about it, because in the operation which is in this chapter, often there is a spillage of blood, with which life is lost at the opening of the vein, or an incision on a bruise, or an opening of an exit, or the curing of a wound, or the extraction of an arrow, or an incision on a stone, and those similar: from all of which fear is associated, and terror, and death falls.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you, do not fall into that, for when it falls on you, there is a hesitation, for sometimes people who are fallen in this art with the modes of sickness fall.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For from them is one who grows angry with his illness, and he is lenient when death comes to him: because of the severity which he finds from his disease and the length of his suffering.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And when sickness is born out of fear, which signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And from these he gives you his own hand, and tells you to use it, hoping for health, but his sickness is harmful.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	So then it is not necessary that you agree to him who comes to you from these, whose way is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And be your caution much greater than your greed and your avarice.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume about anything from him unless after certain knowledge that confirms with you what he achieves in succession that is worthy of praise.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And so that you may cure all your sick patients, by prediction and indication of that to which healing is appropriate.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in him there is for you an aid in acquiring fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, O sons, with his wisdom, and may he not take away from you guidance and inspiration: for it is in his power.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I too have arranged this chapter by distinguishing it into chapters, according to what preceded in the Chapter of Cautery from the crown down to the toes: that you may find what you want from him, and what you need.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	Of the Cure of Water which is added to the heads of boys.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	You should know that this illness often happens to boys at puberty: or when the midwife presses the boy's head without lightness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And whenever it also happens for an obscure reason which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I too did not see this illness in anyone but boys, and I would have liked to see all of them die because of it, so that I would leave the work of healing it.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I too saw a boy of those whose head was filled with water, and the head became magnificent every day until he could not sit on himself because of its size, and the moisture increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this moisture, or集 between the skin and bone: or集 under the bone above the socket.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation in that, if there is moisture between the skin and bone, and the pus is small, then you should find a crack in the middle of the head in width: and the length of the crack is almost two knots, until the moisture runs.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the form of the needle.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If then the moisture is increased and the pus is larger, then place them two cracks, according to this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the moisture is under the bone, and the sign of it is that you see the scalp open from all sides: and when you compress it with your hand towards the inside, and it does not hide from you: then you should find in the middle of the head three cracks, according to this way.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision, remove all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then tighten the cracks with rags and dust.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then put the wound under a pot with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the ligaments, and care for the wound with bandages and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not stop tightening the head with equality.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the sick with dry food and little moisture until they recover their strength and heal.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	Another way of cutting is so that you take into account where the pus appears in size, and the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	Because when it is more in the back, or in the front, or on the right, or on the left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	So go up with the incision where it appears to you pus and filling: and cut it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe, so that you do not hit an artery, and there is a flow of blood, and the sick person dies from that flow with the evaporation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	Of the Incision of Arteries that are behind the ears.
Caput II.	Head II.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When an ulcer occurs on the eye or chest and it is old and does not respond to medical treatment: then the last resort is to cut open these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	It is necessary therefore when you incise them, so that the sick man may shake off his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then fear the place with a rough cloth, so that the arteries appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then the sick man should tie his neck with any of his cloths.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the pulse beats.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the places of each are those which are behind the depressed ears: and rarely is it concealed, unless in certain men.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then marks with caustic on each: and cut each with a needle sharply, the incision extending to the nose: and let it go round the head by its width.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if the eye, introduce the needle under the artery, and cut it towards the top with an incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be as two fingers joined together.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the vein is incised, blood flows out with a pulsating movement, which ascends to the inside at regular intervals.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	But if the artery does not appear by touch, then it is necessary that you measure from the ear the quantity of space of two fingers' breadth.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then marks with caustic, and bring to a stop at the nose.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And what needs to be released from blood is 6 minims, and perhaps you release more or less of it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All this depends on the quantity which appears to you from the vein as it fills, and on the fullness of the artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider towards the ear.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if there remains at the nose any soft stuff, then cut it so that it does not happen a boil which is hot: then tie the ear with a linen thong.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for yourself with ointment, until you are healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	Regarding the extraction of arteries, which are in the temples.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When a man has an old headache, or acute catarrh because of acrid humidities and heat in the lacertae of the temple, or old soda, bitter, and like things: and is treated with the methods of medicine, and does not admit this: then we are skilled in these diseases in extracting the arteries from the temples, or cauterizing them, as we have related.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of operation in extracting them is this: that the sick person's hair which is in the temples be shaved, and be directed towards the appearing artery in the temple.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	And it itself shows you from its pulse, and seldom hides itself unless in a few men, or bitter cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	That if it is hidden from you, then the sick person should tie his head with any of his clothes: and then he should cover the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or with hot water, until it appears to you by a clear sign.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take a needle, which is slightly made in the shape of a point.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then scrape with it the skin easily, until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then put into it a hook, and extract it upwards, until you have taken it out of the skin, and make it ooze from the tunics which are under it on all sides.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If, however, the artery is fine: then turn it with the end of the hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut off a portion from it on the second side according to how long its ends are extended and turn them towards each other, so that blood does not flow out.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not cut, and if it is not separated, the blood will not rise inwardly.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then let the blood flow from it by six ounces up to three.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	That if the artery is large: then it should be tied to it in two places with double thread, strong and smooth: or with the tendon of a horse, so that it does not come under putrefaction before the healing of the wound, and blood flows out.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut off the superfluous flesh, which is between two ligaments.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do that at that hour, or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with the cauldron up to the nose, with a sharp knife: until the extremities are cut off and it remains in its place of work.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And that is better work, unless he has a fever or a hot skin.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	For the cauldron is from those who remain to end the moisture.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is better to bandage.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And after extracting the arteries, so that the place may be filled with old cooking: and put on top of it a little bit of wool made up.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the solution is cured with dry medicines, which make the flesh grow, and with liniments, until it heals.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	That if while you are operating blood flows out from an artery, then hurry to cut it off with a cauldron, or as if you fill the place with bandages: and tighten your hand, until the blood is cut off.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	That if there is nothing present for you, then put your finger on the place, until the blood freezes.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And dip the place with water of cold heat, until the sting stops and is tightened according to what needs to be done.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And from that which is lighter and easier to extract the artery, it is, as if the cauldron holds two knives: and the sharpness of the two knives is like an almond.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	However, they are much less sharp than the two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	For if they are sharp, as the two knives, it is appropriate that both have coldness: and do not cut into the flesh with speed.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	But when there is a little bit of roughness in them, it holds the heat of fire and cuts the flesh quickly: so that this work is better for all work, lighter, and easier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And make space between the two knives according to the thickness of a finger after you have marked the two places with wax: and place the both fires far away until they come to the mouth, and fall a little on both places so that it will be extended what is between its ends.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For with this wax not do they consolidate in depth.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the form of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	Of the cure, course of tears, acuteness, from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When there are persistent tears and there is a course of tears from the ears that are on the outside of the head: and there is no benefit to them with the medicines of doctors, and his eyes begin to turn red, and he feels a trembling in his forehead, as if it were the trembling of ants: and his eyelids are warmed by the acuteness of the tears: then the ancient people found benefits in this operation for their cure, and they called it the cure with Ense.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And is, that you shave off the hair that is on his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then cut in the forehead three incisions that are equidistant according to the length of the forehead: and make the length of the incision almost like two fingers, and let the incision that is in the middle of the forehead be equidistant according to the length of the nose, and the second according to the length of a lizard's movement, and the third from the other one by half its length: and be careful not to cut the arteries that are on both sides. And extend your hand from the continuation of the two jawbones, and make space between each incision according to the thickness of three joined fingers: and have you a prepared sponge or many dry cloths with which you squeeze out the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then introduce the spit end of two acute ends, whose following form is:
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision that is on the side of the time, to the incision that is the second one: and scrub all the skin between the two incisions with the chisel, which is above the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then also cut this from the middle to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then also remove this scythe-shaped piece, and introduce into the first incision again a different tool called a sharp chisel from one side, not acute from the other side.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its acute side against the flesh attached with skin, and its blunt side against the bone: and push it, until it reaches the middle crevice: and cut off with it all the waste that descends from the head to the eyes: except that which continues the incision until it appears from the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then also make this in the middle crease until another crease.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And when an equal quantity of blood has run out, express the places from the clotted blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then also put into every crease a piece of leather from old cloth, and put on them wicks soaked with wine, or oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And tie so that it does not happen a blister hot.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day loosen the ligaments, and administer a strong infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then also care for this with basilicon ointment, and with the others which are used for wounds: until it is healed.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	§ On the treatment of acute lágrimas and cataracts to the eyes from inside the head.
Caput V.	Head.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When there occur to someone a sharp, bitter, and persistent Cataract, and the eyes seem weak, pale, and already declining in aspect: and the eyelids are ulcerated, and hairs fall out of them, and there is a sharp pain in the depth of the head, and consequent sneezing: then remove these accidents, that those materials, and the Cataract do not come, unless they are removed with many tools.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And the best treatment for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is, as you order to the sick person to shave his forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then also make in it one crease in the middle of the forehead, or somewhat less in width, and begin with the crease from the left time to the right time: and continue the incision until you reach the bone: and extend your hand from the jawbones that move during mastication: until it is stopped when it reaches the bone: and you will dry out all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two lips of the wound with a hot cloth, or with silk from linen.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then tighten from above with thread: and immerse the thread in wine and oil so that a hot swelling does not occur.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you loosen it, and you will see that a hot swelling has already begun to emerge: then it is necessary for the surgeon to open the mouth, until the flesh begins to grow there.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then take care of the patient with dry healing that makes flesh grow: as if you took two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony: and prepare a plaster, and administer it to the birth of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	Regarding the care that falls on gold.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	All that falls on gold is of four kinds: either mineral stone, or similar stones, such as iron and silver; or it is from a plant, such as beans and peas; or it is a fluid substance, such as water and vinegar, and similar things; or some creature.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When, then, it falls on gold, or any kind of stone that does not add to the gold and does not grow in it, expose the gold to the sun alone: but if you see a stone, then distill in gold some of the oil that has been cooked, or sesamum.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then administer the extraction and make it snort with condiments, and polverize the nose at the approach of sneezing, after you have placed around the ears twigs of linen or wool, and raise the auricle towards the top.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	Because this treatment is often repeated.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	If, however, it does not go out, then administer the extraction with gestures, that is, with subtle pizgaroli: whose form is this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If, then, it goes out with a gesture, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then administer the extraction with a black hook that is subtle and made of little pieces.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If then he does not come out by that way, then make a tube of brass, and insert the extremity of the tube into the opening of the ear much, and the dust that is in the circumference of the tube with the soft metal with oil, so that there is no route except for the tube: then remove it with your吸引力 forte.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	For many times he went out with him whom we have described.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	But if he does not go out in this way, then take from the calaminum, or from the water, that is to say, the prepared gluten, with which they bind the birds, with which put the metal when it is hot, and set him at the end of the radius after you have dried the ear of the humidity: then insert him into the opening of the ear with ease, after you have dried the ear from the humidity.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If then he does not go out with all that we have described, then approach to cut off, before the hot apoplexy happens, or the spasm.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the mode of the incision is so, that the phlebotome cuts off the sick one first of all in the head: and then remove from it the blood according to the measure of its power.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the sick one sit between your hands, and turn his ear upwards, and find a small hole at the base of his ear in his fat in a depressed place: and let the hole be lunar-shaped, until you have reached the rock: then remove it with that one, which is possible for you from the instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then suer the hole from your time with speed, and tend to it, until it is healed.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	That if what falls into the ear is from one grain, which grows, and swells up: then administer the extraction of it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	But if it does not obey you to come out, then take a thin, delicate stick, according to this form.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with that one the cutting off of its kind from a grain, which falls into the ear, and do not make it, when you think, that it is already moistened by the humidity of the ear, until you have put many whips on it: then remove them with a hook, or with a subtle gesture, or with suction, as we have said, for the extraction of it is eased.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	But the water that is put into the ear should be used by the sick man with a stirrup first of all; and he has already filled his ear with some cooked salt; and he lies on the ear where the water is.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	So if he goes out through that, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	But if not: then take many small stones, according to the length of a finger, soft, dull, and heat them slightly with fire; and let the sick man put one into the hole of his ear: and he should salt his foot on that side, and hit it with another stone on the stone that is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	So let them not cease to do this with stones and stones until he has gone out all water.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And he has already gone out water so that you take from the fire or from one branch and put its end into his ear; and you light that end with fire until it is well burned.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then take another branch and do this many times until he has gone out all water; and pull it out with a tube according to what was said before in the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	But when extracting what has entered into it, if it is a small body, like a flea, and like it, take care of it as I said in the division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it seems to be a large body, then administer its extraction with gestures and hooks; and the work of it is easier for all those who hold it in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	But when extracting the black dog that is in the ear, if your care seems to be the same as what we said in the division and in the book of distillation, and does not seem to be helpful; then you should examine the ear in the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	But if there appears anything of that sort out there, then extract it with gestures or with subtle hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	But if nothing appears out there, then take the tube which has this form: narrow below, wide above; and put its thin end into the ear according to the tolerance of the sick man: and then suck it up with a strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	So that many times, until all the worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	But if they don't obey you to go out, then dip the cane around them with chalk, as I said on the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	That if they don't go out with it that we said: then administer the distillation which the ancient have already experienced in the infection of worms: and you will find that in the treatise on distillation.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And may your flow be as it is when you pour oil and medicine into the ear with this instrument, whose form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you see, do make the hole of silver or brass, narrow below, and wide above.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	So that it is driven as it is in the squeeze of the cane, let it be made of brass, made askew.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you want to take the liquid, and pour it into the ear with the cane, let it be made of brass, made askew. And if you want to heat it slightly, let it be heated with fire, and let there not be anything that is distilled into it, for medicines do not tolerate that.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	On the treatment of the disease of gold.
Caput VII.	Head VII.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	When some children come out of their mothers' wombs unpierced.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it also happens to some people that there is an opilation in the ear of gold from a wound, or flesh grown in it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this opilation sometimes happens in a deep hole of gold, which is not caused by heat: and when it happens to the external holes a little, it is caused by heat.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	That which happens in a deep hole of gold, and which is not comprehended by appearance, is difficult to heal in many dispositions.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And in that which is caused by heat, you should put gold into the sun, and look in it: then if you see an opilation appearing, open it with a sharp tweezers, whose form is as follows, let the end of it be in a small curvature, some of its part being acute: and let the other tweezers side be soft: so that it does not hurt the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If then an inflammation has arisen from the flesh in the meatus auris: then hold it with a fine hook and cut it easily with a sharp instrument until the whole is cut away.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	That if an inflammation is in the deep part of the ear: then take a thin ray, soft and heat it slightly: then put it into the meatus auris.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If then you feel an inflammation with it, that which occurs when there is loss of hearing due to weight: be careful in removing it easily; and being careful, do not injure the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then put into the ear a liquid of the quantity of width of the pore that you have opened with Egyptian ointment: let it be for several days until you are cured of the injury.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take liquid and pour it into rose water, and pulverize it on it, and use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	That if you see the ear already infected: then it is necessary that you take out the liquid, and let it be with other liquid, which you have put in greenwort that is made with rose water, until it cools down the infection; then care for the ear until it is cured.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If then there is a flow of blood: then dip a sponge, or cloth in cold water and put it on the ear; and use what remains of the cure, which stops the predicted flow of blood in the treatment of distillation.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	Of the cure of the palpebrae of Albithis.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These are the things that occur in the eyelids of the eye when they are moist and dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Then you should hold them with tongs: or with a hook, and cut them off at the roots.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then put on the places greenwort.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	If then there flows blood from them, then you should burn them with a small lens.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And burning them is better after cutting.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	Often they return when a little remains of the roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned up, and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	On the treatment of the eyelids of the eye.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Often it happens in the eyelids that something is absorbed by Crandinus in his strength and dureness, and on account of this he is called Grandinus; and it is an aggregation of a thick moisture in the upper lid, and in the lower lid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	Operation therefore on them is, that you consider then, if it is Grandinus proceeding from the eye, which appears on the lid, and moves to all parts, and the thing is easy.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Find therefore over it a slit from side to side.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape her thoroughly from all parts with ease, until it bleeds.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend her by a hook, and cut her off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	But if you are not prepared to cut it off, unless you penetrate the eyelid with an incision just a little, then it will hurt the injured part in some way.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	That if the slit is wide: then aggregate her together with sutures: and take care of her, until she heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, do not cause harm to her from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	The unguents restore the same, and inflame her.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if Grandinus is a fall into the inner parts opposite to the surface inwardly, then turn round the eyelid, and suspend Grandinus by a hook: except that you should make an incision, and press her from all sides.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	That if the eyelid is elongated by an incision, then it does not hurt the injured part in any way.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash out the eye after Grandini's incision with salt water; and take care of the place where it is inflamed, until the injured part heals.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On the treatment of the eyelids of the eye.
Caput X.	Chapter X.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is a dew that forms in the eyelids of the upper eye: and indeed this often happens to boys: and it grates their eyes, and they get cataracts in the morning, and cannot see the light of the sun, because tears flow towards them, and for this reason they always lie on their faces, and sleep on top of them, and their eyelids are wet under their brows, which have already been inflated by swelling: and the prominence of Axirnath is indeed apparent to the eye, and when you press the place with your fingers, you feel Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the mode of its operation is that he should put his sick head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth and prepare it with folds, and make it into a circle according to the quantity that contains Axirnath from all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place it on top of it, and press it with your fingers from all sides so that Axirnath gathers in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of its humidity with a sharp instrument that has a sliver of skin attached to it, and there is no larger wound than that which is made in phlebotomy in the deep.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or you should find all the skin, until you reach Axirnath, because Axirnath often proceeds from a wound in many places: for indeed Axirnath arises from white skin.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Then remove it with the cloth that you have soaked between your fingers towards the outside: and you should open your hand to the right and left until it disperses: and carefully, do not add it to the wound, so that you do not hit the eye with the knife, and let it go.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	But if Axirnath does not appear to you at first from the wound, you should add a little to the wound with ease until Axirnath begins to come out.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then remove it, as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then immerse the cloth in vinegar and water, and place it on the spot, and tighten it with dust.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And there are people who wrap themselves with salt, and they put it on the wound of a裂口，to make what is left of that humidity melt.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then take care of herself, until she heals.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	But if it happens on the spot of an abcess a hot place, then take care of himself with cooled plasters, until she heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	The way of the Ataxmir eyes, that is, when the eyelid becomes soft to the eye, so that it grows like it should not be.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When they grow in the eyelids of hair added beyond the course under the natural hairs, and increase: then they hurt the eye, and cause diseases, such as constant tears, and softening of the eyelids, and alba
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And the Ataxmir eyes are cared for according to four ways.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cauterization with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with sharp medicine, according to which is stated in the chapter of cauterization.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or the Ataxmir are cared for by incision and suturing.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or with needles, according to which I say:
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	It should be placed on the head of the nurse in your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn towards the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	But if it is turned, that is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not: push it into where there is a hair from the lower part of the eyelid, and let it pierce with the thread up, and let it be close to the natural hairs, that is, close to the edge of the eyelid, where the hairs grow: and pull the thread upwards with the eyelid, and turn it around.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find on the inner side of the eyelid under the added hairs with a sharp instrument incident from the larger tear to the smaller tear.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then pull out the thread, and put under the eyelid a small piece of bread or cloth: then seal with enxert on the eyelid, which is like the figure of a leaf of myrrh.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	It is indeed necessary that the figure be made according to the quantity and elevation of the eyelid: for this has already been diverse among men.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	From these it is indeed necessary that the figure be made according to the quantity and elevation of the eyelid: for this has already been diverse among men.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then when you find the edge of the eyelid with a spatulum on two lines that you have marked, and begin from the larger tear to the smaller, and place one slit next to the natural hair, as is the thickness of the radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert the hook into one of two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then scrape it all out.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then gather together with sutures the two lips, with an awl and a fine thread: and wipe away the blood, and let what is superfluous adhere to the two eyebrows, with some things that are invisible, if you want to do this: and if not, then it does not matter.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then let go of the suture and thread up to three or four days: then take care of that.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you want, let go of the hook without a suture, and take care of it with it, that it dries up and tightens.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid is lifted at the seal of the wound and its aggregation: but the future one is better.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	In this way, Ataxmir taught to heal.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	But in that is a concern about the sick, and it is from a good operation, and there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another way of Ataxmir too: and it is, that the figure on the eyelid is like the shape of a bay leaf, as we have reported.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then lift the eyelid with three separate or aggregated hooks, according to this shape that follows, then cut off what is superfluous with little scissors, according to this form, with an equal incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	But if it is not possible for you to hold the hook, and it does not fit that way: then take the thread in which is the hook, and insert it into the middle of the figure: and insert another thread next to the larger tear, and a third next to the smaller tear: and gather the threads between your fingers with an equality.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then anoint your hand with a equal amount of ointment: and anoint the skin over what is marked by the bandage, as we have said.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather together two lips of the wound with a stitch: and care for it, until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	If however an abscess happens to be at your incision, or a hole: but that abscess with caustic, and such like, should be seated from the ointment.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And when ever the eyelids also turn in, so as to turn his hairs.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore you should use that which we have said for an incision: but the stitch is more artificial.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	For the care of Ataxmir with needles.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And is, when you turn the eyelid, and cut the hole which is within, according to what we have said.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then artfully make two needles, or two thin sticks: the length of which should be according to the length of the eyelid, and their width less than the width of a toothpick: and you have already stitched at the ends of both sides where you hold the thread.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then gather each one with a thread over what is in excess from the eye-lid, and strongly tighten two needles from both sides, and let it go for some days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the skin is stiff, it will die, and it will rot away, until it falls away by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If however it should be delayed, then cut it with razors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it, until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When however it is hardened, the eyelid is to be anointed, and the hairs are not pricked.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the form of two needles which you should make according to this figure, and the quantity in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	For anointing the stinging hairs in the eye with an acorn.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation in that case is, that you should take a thin acorn, and insert it into a thread of silk, and string it up.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then join the extremities together with sutures, and tie each knot with a fine thread: and let the length of the threads be one palm.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then make another thread from linen thread, shorter than that, and tie the ends together with a knot.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then let the sick person lie close to your chest, near the sun, that the operation may be declared: for the operation is subtle or minute.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then insert the awl from the linen thread into the root of the eyelid, and let it pierce through the eyelid swiftly, until it comes out on top of the natural pimple.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then draw the awl all the way up to the linen thread: and insert the awl into the linen thread: if it is one, or two, or three, not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then draw your hand away with it, until the pimple comes out with the linen thread along with the natural pimple in the eyelid.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	If however the linen thread is pulled out, and does not come out with it: take the linen thread from below, with the thread that you have composed in it, until you can pull out the linen thread from the upper opening, and cut off the eye-lid with it: then pull out both, and close the eye, and let him stay closed for two or three days, until the pimple has come to head, and a pimple has grown up on its place, and covered it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the thread is short, then either attach a long thread from the natural pimple, and let it come out with it: or let him go, until he grows longer by space, and then let him out.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	The treatment of Al-Akhrawi that occurs in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII: On the Treatment
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this happens to the eye, it is called Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this Al-Akhrawi treatment is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	So this Al-Akhrawi treatment is either from the union of a pimple with a skin fragment, or from a cut, or from cauterization, and similar to these.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the mode of operation in her is, that you may find her consolidation, and that you separate her lips, and put in it what is between them licinio from linen, and bind her, until she be healed.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And it is not fitting that you should use in her things which dry and constrict, for if you do this, she will return worse than before; but rather use in her things which soften, such as fennel seed: and steep it with water in which althaea has been boiled, linen seed: and unguent with dyaquilon, which is liquid when mixed with some of the oils: and apply licinium to it, and cure with it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And the treasure of your cure is, that you may seek all contrivance, that she not consolidate, according to the form which she had in the beginning.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this operation which we have described is nothing else than a certain correction of Albacasis, that she not return to her form, according to which she was entirely.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	Regarding the cure of Albacasii which is done in the lower eyelid, and is a rubbing or contraction upward toward the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XXII.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This of Albacasii which is done below is what is truly called Albacasis.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is natural, and is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And the accidental one is done from a wound, or a crease, or a scar, and such like.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the mode of operation in her is, that you take an acorn, in which there are two threads, and touch it to the flesh, and cause it to penetrate from the left tear to the right, until the two ends of the thread come to the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then extend the flesh upward with a nail, and strike it with an awl on the side.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If then the form of the eyelid returns according to what is necessary, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take a ray, and put it in the crease, and turn it with it: and find two creases on the inner side of the eyelid, and are the ends of the two creases from two angles of incision, until they meet and form one angle: until when they are gathered together, may that figure be made, and is a Greek letter.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh by quantity, which is his acute lower side, from him who follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then collect the separate parts and sew them together with a woolen thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then take care of them with that which I have said, concerning soothing medicines and bandages, until they are healed.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if an axillary wound occurs in a fissure, and needs to be sutured or cauterized: then you should find a flat fissure under the eyelids, also depending on what preceded it.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate the two lips with a lint, as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the main words about the care of axillary wounds, whether they are upper or lower, so that the operation proceeds according to the preparation of Albucasis' form.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For it itself is very different in form: and the skilled craftsman prepares his art with whatever means are possible to him, until he restores the figure to the natural shape, or close to it, and himself also becomes ill, as is fitting for him from the operation and instruments in many dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	Regarding the adhesion of the eyelid to the conjunctiva, or the cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	And when this consolidation has happened to many people, so that the upper eyelid is consolidated with the white of the eye, and prevents itself from its own natural operations.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Then you should insert the tip of a ring under the eyelid and lift it up: or you should extend it with a hook: then cut the adhesion with a sharp knife, which is not acute in cutting the skin of a hook, but rather slightly obtuse: so that the sick person does not disturb at the operation, and removes the hook, and hurts his eye with its sharpness: and make your incision as if you were removing it, until when he returns the eyelid to its own natural form, and heals the adhesion entirely.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour into his eye warm salt water, washing it with water: or distil into his eye from a distilled wine made from a dissolved zinc, with water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate the eyelids from the eye with a blade of iron: and place on the eye wool dipped in alum; and after three days use seif, and with solidatives, until it heals.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	On cutting the nail and the eminence of the flesh of the lacrimal gland.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI. On the incision of the nail and the emin
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	Know that the nail is made in two ways.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Or it is nervous: and it is similar to soft, tough sikfah, delicate.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nervous, similar to frozen moisture of snow: which when it touches iron, or is held by a hook, comes off, and does not stick to it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And the two kinds do not begin to form until from the greater lacrimal gland, gradually, until they have acquired moisture, and prevent light, and eye movement.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of working on its incision is: so that he may place his head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open his eyes, and separate his eyelids with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then take the nail with a small hook, and extend it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a pin and insert it into the nail from among the nails of a horse, or a hook: and make the thread strong, and double its end slightly, and fix it in the middle of the nail: and pierce it with an awl, and tie the nail thread onto it, and extend it upwards: and scrape off with a hair the side of the nail that follows the pupil, as if you were closing it up with hair until the very edge of its rear end.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then make a small incision in the root of the lacrimal gland with a sharp scalpel, or with small forceps: and remove the natural tissue of the lacrimal gland, so that no constant flow of tears occurs from its incision.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And when the nail is extended with a hook alone: or with thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then scrape with a soft sponge, this is its shape.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And let not the sponge touch the horny tunic, and let not an injury occur to it, and let not the pupil be punctured.
