Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	That if corruption is in the joint, then cut that joint corruption, and close the bone where it continues from the other part.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	But if corruption is in the continuation of two joints, then there is no strength in that except for a scar.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	That if corruption is in the palm, or in the sole: then the matter is difficult to mend very much.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	It is true that you should inquire how corruption appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And if it cracks, dry it and make it as clean as you can by means of whatever instrument is at hand and whatever skill you possess: when it does not give a contrary vein or nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that there are many chisels and saws for cutting these bones, depending on the position of the bones and their preparation, and their thickness and fineness, and their size and porosity, and their hardness and their rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore you should prepare instruments suitable for all kinds of operations.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations require a long-term study of the instrument you are using.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And knowledge of these ways of practice is a testimony to the types of sicknesses: for then you will find out by yourself what is suitable for him from instruments, for every disease.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I confirm to you at the end of this chapter the number of instruments, which you place as examples for those that you cut, and a proof from your experience on other ones.
Forma Serrae.	(Shape of the Saw)
Forma alterius Serrae.	(Shape of another saw)
Forma Serrae alterius.	(Shape of yet another saw)
Forma Serrae alterius.	(Shape of still another saw)
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This shape of the saw is slightly off-centered.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its bow be curved upward, and its keenness from iron: and its handle from beech, and its pyramid-like shape slightly off-centered.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	(Shape of the scalpel)
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	(The head of this scalpel is shaped like a star-shaped claw): and its dots are shaped like the dots of an elk's horn.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it is not suitable unless it rubs against the scalpels when it is cutting, when it is corroded, or has a wide and large mouth, and is great in size.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	(Shape of a larger scalpel)
Forma medii Rasorii.	(Shape of a medium-sized scalpel)
Forma Rasorii lati.	(Shape of a wide scalpel)
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The shape is sharp.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The shape is sharp.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The shape is sharp.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The shape is sharp.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The shape is sharp.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	The shape is also sharp.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is similar to the radio, and the end is like a saw: it appears in many places from the cutting of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The shape is sharp, which is suitable for its incision, as it is pierced through bone.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	The end of it is triangular, and its ends are acute.
Fit ex Indi.	This fits from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And likewise it is necessary that all that we have said of the rasors, and the incisers, and the saws be made.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	Regarding the incision of ends, and the sawing of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Head 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The ends rot, either from an external cause, or an internal one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	But when the patient has been cured by medicines, and does not respond to treatment with medicines, and you see corruption affect a limb, but it does not spread to the whole body, so it is necessary to cut off that limb to where the corruption spreads, so that the sick person is saved from death, or from a greater defect of the limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that has happened to it, namely that it becomes corrupted, should be cut off until it is cured: for fire burns it and puts out its ardor, or腐敗後，直到它被治好：當它腐朽到身體那部分，並蔓延到全身。
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Then approach it with care, and likewise, if the cause of corruption is from percussion of certain venenosae (poisonous creatures): such as the sea scorpion, the spider, the rat, and others.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	Then if corruption, or percussion is at the end of a finger, then cut off the finger, and not leave room for corruption, so that it is cut off up to the remaining hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And likewise, if it happens in the hand, then cut it from the root with a sharp knife, and not leave room for corruption, until it is taken off into the sharp-witted arm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it has broken into it, then incision is made on the arm at the joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if corruption has passed through, and you see him around the hip: then death is in him.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to administer in addition to this cure, is a quantity of virtue.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And likewise do for the foot, when corruption has entered into a toe, then incision is made on it at one of the joints: and if it has entered into the nail of the toe, then incision is made on the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it has ascended to the knee, then incision is made on the leg at the joint of the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	That which if corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no power in it, except for discharge, and leave behind the sick to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the mode of incision on the limb, or of wrapping it up is, so that you tighten the ligaments below, which you wish to incise: and tighten another ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And let one minister extend a ligament to the lower: and let another minister extend a ligament upward to the upper.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate flesh which is between the two ligaments, with your finger, until all the flesh is visible.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then incision is made, or it is wrapped up.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it should be so, that you put a cloth from all parts before the wound, and so that it does not touch the healthy place of the incision: and so that the sick person suffers from injury, added to it, and the swelling is hot.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	But if blood flows inward while you are working, then the place is quickly burned: or put on it some powder which cuts the blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your own medication, until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then wrap the wounded limb with a suitable ligament, and care for it, until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you what happened to the man in his foot, this is the same accident that I tell you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because it happened in his black foot, when the ash which resembles the burning of fire: and that corruption first occurred in one of his toes, until it began his entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	So the wound was healed when he saw that a boil had formed on his limb, which he felt due to pain and itchiness, and he cut it open at the joint, and was cured.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, the same corruption again occurred to him on his finger of his right hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	So he came to me and I tried to remove the excess with him when I put on his hand some medicines after purifying his body: and there was no response to the excess, and it began to itch again on another finger: until the corruption began to spread on the hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He called me to cut off his hand: and I did not want to do so, hoping for a response from it regarding the excess: and I was afraid even of cutting off his hand himself.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For the strength of the arm was above falling.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	After he had despaired of me, he turned back to his land: and he approached me about it, because he wanted to recover, and he cut off all his hand: and he was cured.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not bring this story forward except to make it an aid in the case of such a sickness: and that it may be a sign, and according to what is relevant.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Regarding the treatment of boils, and the quality of the lancing with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 100.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When a boil occurs in some fleshy member, and the boil remains for a long time without breaking, until it makes the juice rise: then it bursts, or pierces, and the pus that is in it comes out, leaving a hole like a wound, and the skin over it becomes like a thin cloth: and it does not reach the end of its corruption, nor prints into the bone, nor into the tendons, neither does it touch the ligaments: it seemed to be called a Sinus: but it is not called a Fistula: however, if it prolongs that space, until it prints the corruption on some of those limbs, then it is called a Fistula, or a pustule.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the cure is such that you should strike off all of the skin like a garment; and most especially when it has been thinned out, and made like a piece of cloth; and be confident because it would not adhere to the place, for its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you hope that the skin will adhere, and does not follow from it that corruption: and if there is a thickness of flesh there, then the cure itself with the use of the plaster: and is, as you should consider towards the sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large, and the pus that is discharged from it has a foul odor: then plaster it itself with the use of Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, oil, and myrrh, equal parts, mixed together in a vessel; and let it boil on the fire until it turns red: and let it come to a consistency of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what you need: and dissolve it with water and honey, and plaster it up with the sinuses; and tightly close the opening, and release the medicine into it for a duration of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with an expression: let it be for days, until the sinuses are cleaned out, and the smell is gone.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And whenever you plaster it with water of ash, when this medicine is not present: and is, as you should take ash from wood of oak, or ash from oak-wood: and pour it over the ash.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then dip it in, and plaster it up with it, until you are confident that the sinuses are now clean.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	That if the sick person does not tolerate the Egyptian medicine and water of ash, then plaster it itself with water and honey, in which has already been mixed a little crushed myrrh.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or plaster it itself with honey and wine because the property of honey is to clean and wash away: and the wine makes the sinuses adhere, especially when there is a surplus of stinginess and dryness.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	Whenever you do this, and are convinced that corruption has already been removed: then cleanse him with water along with what he does to give birth to flesh within him.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And is, that you take from an ointment dyafinicon: and dissolve it with oil of roses, and wine astringent: or cleanse him with certain medicines, and other ointments, whose properties I have written in a book about ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	That if the opening of the sinus is strict, in which the cannula of the clister does not enter: then increase it slightly with iron: or put in it a little licorium that has been infused in Egyptian ointment, or in basilicon ointment, until it increases.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And also if the opening is also wide, then add the lips together with a stitch: and let go out of it a quantity in which the clister enters without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And also if the opening from which there runs pus is raised upwards: then dry it in a lower place which is in it, so that the pus runs down: for when the pus is held back in the depth of the sinus, it prevents flesh from being generated in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	That if it is not possible for you to dry the sinus all around below it according to what you want: then be careful, that you prepare the member with a preparation which runs out of it pus easily according to which you are prepared.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Be careful, that nothing of the pus is retained within it at all: and take medicines that are put on the patch, which are suitable for the sinus you want.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them over a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And place such a quantity of the cloth so that it communicates with all of the sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with pincers into the direct opening of the sinus hole, a slightly larger opening of the sinus.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend from the ointment soft things over another cloth according to the quantity of the hole: and place it on the member at a distance from the opening of the sinus so that it allows the exit of pus out of it: and do not remove the large cloth, unless after a few days one time.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	But he who is above the sinus opening, is he who moves at all times so that he goes out what is gathered in him from pus; and know that this which runs out of it virus, is much or little: or digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when you consider this place again of the sinus itself, does he not feel the master's pain, or is there no pain in it, and is there a pimple in it, or is there no pimple?
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	So when your treatment extends thus far, and you see the matter that comes out over the sinus opening, then know that the sinus is already attached, or approaching attachment; so then dissolve it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you dissolve the wart, then change the cloth with another, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if the virus comes out of the sinus after a long time interval, then do not despair of its attachment, for its healing approaches, because from men there are those who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and from them there are those who act in opposition to it.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if it comes out of the sinus after many days with undigested pus, then know that the sinus does not attach.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	But if the attachment of the sinus is delayed and its course is prolonged, then add to the drying up of medicines, truly let doctors do so that they be in their substance moist, and in their virtue dry: as the balm of daphnescene, when added thereto an excess of addition with zagi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the greater part, when it is cured, take the balm of daphnecene, and dissolve it with rose oil, and let it flow over the old wart in equal substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then bind it up with that, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And this same action of yours is similar to that of the balm of daphnecene when it is not present with you, honey when you heat it up until it thickens, and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Take myrrh, and aloe, and olibanum: mix them together and reduce them to a fine powder, and sprinkle it on honey while it is being heated.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then cover the wound with a cloth, and bind it tight over the sinew: and cover the cloth with the honey you have prepared, until it has thickened: and sprinkle the powder on the wound, and put the cloth back over it, and bind it tight.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And when this is applied to him, take long-leaved aristochaos and the roots of the star lily, and there is a lily; and herb flour, and the daisy.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them in their simple state, or crushed up, mix them well, and sprinkle the powder on the honey you have prepared, and use that.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the injury does not heal with this treatment, then know that there is corruption in its depths; or it has already made an impression on the bones, or the other hard organs, or the ligaments: then treat it with treatments for fistulas, as has been set out.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Of the treatment of finger injuries and the use of ointments and incisions of the fingers and their sectioning.
Caput XCI.	Chapter LXI
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Is a finger injury that arises under the nail of the thumb or another finger, and perhaps it also arises in the other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	But when this injury persists and its treatment is neglected, and it becomes infected with pus: or it corrupts, and discharges it from the nail root: and perhaps it corrupts all of it, and perhaps the corruption reaches the mouth, until it has a foul smell: and the tip of the finger becomes swollen, and its color turns dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When you treat this finger, following the division that we have described, and your treatment does not bring about a cure: then you must cut off all the excess that remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the finger after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	For a cauterized wound is very hot.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If the bone is actually sound, and the nail also is sound, and the calluses of the nail are already pressing the flesh to the interior, and they begin to sting it, and hurt it: then it is necessary that you put Radium subtil under the angle of the nail which stings the flesh, and push it upward: and cut the flesh with ease, and place over it what remains of the meat from the medicines burning, scorched until all of it has moved.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then the care for that with the nail, until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If however the corruption has already impressed on the bone, then it is necessary that you cut that bone and take it out: for the bone does not heal at all while it remains in it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	That if you see the corruption and the corruption entering into the finger, then cut it at one of its joints, according to what has been said above in memory of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then the care for the finger, until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If however there is a loss of the nail, or a knock: and there comes into it a severe pain, then it is necessary that you draw blood from the injured part at first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with a sharp Spatula from above towards the nail.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And guard, so that the cut does not reach the flesh under the nail: for you will cause to happen through it a severe pain in the injured part, and it will be a cause of birth of flesh added in place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then the care for the place with him that sits with the pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The finger however that is added which is born in some hands of men, perhaps is fleshy all over: and perhaps are bones in it, and perhaps has a nail there: and the birth of some of its joints, or is the birth in some of its joints of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	This one then that is born in some joints of the finger does not move: and this one that is born at the joint of the finger, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, he who has flesh, his sectioning is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, so that you strike him at the root with a broad flat chisel.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But as for the one whose birth is in the root of the joint, his cure is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	So then abstain from incising him.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	But as for the one who is born in a finger at the very last of the nodes, then you must strike him first with a round incision all the way down to the jaw.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then tighten the jaw with one of the appropriate saws for that.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then cure him, until he is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	But as for the consolidation that has occurred in the fingers, it often happens or from the birth of man, that is, he is born with it, or from the consolidation of the wound, or from the burning of fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	So then let him separate that consolidation, until the fingers regain their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them a linen cloth, or cloths soaked in rose oil: so that they do not quickly consolidate, and separate them from each other: or place between them a thin lead sheet, until the area is consolidated as it should be.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly, if a consolidation occurs in some fingers with the palm, then dry out that consolidation, according to how it is prepared and suited for the shape of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	Regarding the Incision:
Caput XCII.	Chapter LII. The Head.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Veins are swollen, large, and full of melancholy excesses that occur in many parts of the body: and many of them end in the legs, especially in the legs of those who walk a lot, and those who carry loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	So then let him administer to the body a strong exhaustion from black cholera sometimes with an infusion.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then draw blood from the patient's arm with a bowl.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The cure of these veins with iron is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	They should cut off the leg, and draw out the black blood.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And another way is, that they should cut away the vein, and draw all of it out.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The sectioning, however, is according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	First wrap the leg with warm water until the black, foul blood dissolves.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then tie the leg by the upper part of the hip, all the way down to the knee with sutures.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then cut off a wide strip of vein at one, two, or three places.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then squeeze the blood out by hand from the lower part of the leg, all the way up to the top, and it should be done first by the phlebotomist so that the patient does not faint.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then cut off the nail down to the bottom: until a quantity of blood is shed which you see is sufficient, and which the strength of the nurse can tolerate.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then tie it up: and command him to abstain from foods that generate black cholesterol; and again, to let go of the blood when the veins are filled, and this will harm the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The raising, however, is according to this method.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Shave the leg if there are many hairs.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then put him in a bath, or wrap him in the leg with warm water until he reddens, and the veins burst; or exercise him strongly if there is no bath present, until he warms the limb.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then cut off the skin according to the direction of the vein along its length: or at the end of the leg at the knee, or on the lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with a hook, and scrape off the vein from all parts, until you can see it; and when you see it turn from red to black, you will know that it is the right one.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When, therefore, you have cut off the skin, you will see it white as a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert the rod under it until it comes out and leaves the skin: hang it with a blind hook, soft.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry another piece of flesh next to that piece of flesh with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the buttocks until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then clean it with the rods as you did before, and hang it with another blind hook as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry another piece of flesh or more pieces if you can tolerate it.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then clean it again and cut it last near the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then pull it out to the length of the piece that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And make it so that you pull it out from the upper piece or longer pieces until it comes out completely: then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If it does not submit to you when pulling and cleaning, then insert a strong double thread with her and tie her and pull her out: or insert the rod under it and roll your hand all over it until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And cut, so that it is not cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut, it will be difficult for you to clean it well, and it enters on the injured part of the wound.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When you have completely pulled it out: then place it on the site of the wound that is soaked with wine and oil or rosin, and care for it until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	That if the vine is contracted and has a twist in its parts to which it applies the involution, and is not like what we said according to rectitude: then you should find on it for all the parts of its twist, and the places of its involution.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then hang it with a hook so that you clean it all: and be careful near the cut section on it so that you do not get hurt, or hurt your wound: for it will be difficult to clean it well on you, or pull it out.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Preserve therefore your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	Form of incision where the vine heals.
Forma Vncini caeci.	Form of incisions in a blind person.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not prudence like the rest of the vine, nor has it acute extremities, lest it wound the hand: and it is a great flexibility, soft: for if it were subtle, it would fall on the hand with its subtility: but it has superfluous grossness, as we have said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of a vein from the leg.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter XCI.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is produced in the legs in warm countries, such as that of a horse, and the land of the Arabs, and in arid lands, hot and scarce of verdure, that is to say, where no grass grows, nor trees.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is produced in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is from putrefaction which occurs under the skin, such as happens within the bodies of serpents and flies, and of worms between the skin and meat.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this vein is, that which happens in the leg, a painful inflammation.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the site becomes sore.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to exit from the site of its inflammation, as if it were a root of a plant, or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	So when that end thereof appears, you shall wrap thereon a leaden rod, the weight of which is from a drachm to a centune, to two drachms, and mark it: and let go the lead hanging from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	So whenever anything goes out from it towards the outside, wrap that on a leaden rod, and mark that:
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	That if it is prolonged for a long time, then cut a part of it, and wrap the remnant on a leaden rod.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut that root before it has gone out all together.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you should cut it, it will contract itself, and go into the flesh: and it causes the formation of a boil, and putrefaction in that place, and a bad sore.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	So then it should be handled gently and slowly withdrawn until it has completely emerged from the last of its own, and nothing remains of it in the body: and from this very vein emerges in some men which is in length of five palms and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And already I have reached him, for he has passed out through twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if you are injured during your treatment: then introduce a ray into the opening and pierce it through the long hole with the body until all the matter inside is emptied out: and administer medicine to the site with some drugs for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then take care of yourself in curing the pustules.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this very vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears in the ankle joint of the foot, or in the foot itself: and it has many openings, and emerges from every opening with a branch.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	So take care of yourself, as we have said in the division, and with that which was said above.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	Regarding the section on worms born under the skin, it is called "aegritudo bouina.
Caput XCIIII.	Head 84th
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This sickness is called in some country "Aegritudo bouina" because it often happens that worms are born and there is a scaly single one which is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it makes the whole body move up and down, and shows itself through the movement of a limb to another, until it breaks off at some place on the skin and emerges: and it disappears from that member to another.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its birth is of some corrupted human flesh.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As happen worms and snakes, that is, earthworms and roundworms in the stomach.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And they fear its evil.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it makes itself in the body, and moves to the head, and reaches a place: then perhaps it opens within, and emerges, and destroys the eye: and this happens often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	And so you should take care of him and extract it, then he will not feel that until he walks on it and feels the sensation himself.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	It is necessary therefore that you should tie what is above him and what is below him with strong constriction.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry off on top of him, and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it penetrates the flesh, and not injure him: then place on the spot a caustic with fire, until he dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater what is feared, is corruption of it, which corrupts the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	But if you see him already reaching at the head near the eye, then tie under it a good stricture of the eyebrow.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry off on top of him, and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that the sick one should use his own purification, with physicians dissolving bad putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods that generate putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	[On the section on illness by Nakir.]
Caput XCV.	Chapter L.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This disease is called in our land Nakir: and it is a pain that happens to some member: then it changes from one member to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And indeed I have already seen him, according to what I tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a sick woman in some wombs.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she held out her arm, and I saw an inflammatory swelling in the armpit of the arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour had passed, I saw one swelling go down with fire, like a burn, rising faster than it could go up: so that it is like shining silver when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	Then the pain receded from that place, and was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then after an hour he sat, and ran all over his body until it reached another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then he told me that he was running all over his whole body, according to what I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I marvel therefore at the swiftness with which he changes from one limb to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I too did not see this disease with my eyes before this way.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	But I see many who suffer the pain of change from one limb to another: and I did not see him with my eyes, as I saw him in a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that this is because it is he who is from the scaly limbs of the spotted women: therefore, this sense of change seems to me to arise from that.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary so that they do not appear in this way in those who are delightful and have moist bodies, of hidden women.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	But when you are performing his cure, and the patient feels this pain: then if it appears to you with your eye, as we have said, then lift him up and move him quickly: and dry him above him until he is free of this change: and burn the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	But if you do not see him with your eyes: then cure him by peeling his body, and along with it so that he expels the winds, and makes them red with the help of foul pills and pills made from serapine, and others like them.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	Về việc loại bỏ các gai hành.
Caput XCVI.	Chương 66 đầu.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Gài hành khác nhau theo loài và vị trí của chúng trong cơ thể.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Nhưng có nhiều loại khác nhau: vì có những cái có gai lớn và nhỏ, và tròn, và nhọn, và đen.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	Và trong số chúng có những thứ có ba góc.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	Và từ số đó có lưỡi liềm.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	Và từ số đó có các sao.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Nhưng những thứ nằm theo chiều dọc của các chi thì rơi theo hai cách.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Hoặc những chi chính của cơ thể, chẳng hạn như não bộ, tim, phổi, thận, ruột và bàng quang thì tròn.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When then falls into one of these limbs, and apparent to you are the signs of death, which I shall tell you about later, then it is necessary that you extract this arrow from them, for death follows him where he is, in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these bad signs do not appear to you, and the arrow is not hidden deep within the limb, then extract it, and heal the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For when the signs occur in which the arrow enters the bone and goes out through the skull, it is: for then happen from it violent headache, scotoma, vertigo, reddening of the eyes, swelling, reddening of the tongue, spasm, confusion of thought, and paralysis of cholera.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	and perhaps blood comes out from the nose, or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	and perhaps speech is lost, and speech is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And comes out from the wound place a white, similar to pulp moisture.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And comes out from it a similar liquid of meat.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If then these signs appear to you, then refrain from curing, and extract the arrow if it has not come out.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of the arrow when it falls into the heart are: for it is near the left nipple: and feels as if it were fixed to a hard thing, not to a soft thing.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow has a movement similar to a pulsation: and black blood runs from the limb.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And follows it extreme coldness of the extremities, and cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Know therefore that death has certainly come.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of the arrow when it wounds the lung is the exit of frothy blood from the limb: and the clothes that cover the neck are torn, and their color changes, as the nurses tell.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And breathes a great, deep breath, and seeks cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If the arrow falls into a wound that is in the chest: then it is near to the few ribs: and causes a great, painful sighing with a sigh: and shake all the shoulders of the arms.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if a arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps it will come out of the ulnar bone with some undigested food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if an arrow falls into the belly and lodged therein: it will come out of the ulnar bone, or a piece of dung, or an intestine which has already been broken.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is therefore no hope for his cure, nor for the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If an arrow falls into the bladder and passes out through it: and if anything comes out to the outside, and the pain is greater on the sick person: then you should know that it is a lethal wound.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The rest of the limbs, such as the face, neck, throat, jaw, aid, spine, collarbone, femurs, thighs, legs, and similar bones, are saved according to multiple dispositions: when the arrow does not hit an artery or nerve: and there is no deadly arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I will tell you what I have seen of these arrows, so that you may understand it with regard to your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is, because an arrow fell into the tear duct of a man's eye, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	So I extracted it for him on the other side, under the fat of his ear: and he recovered, and there was no harm to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from the Jew, which had fallen into his fat under his lower eyelid: and the arrow was now hidden, and I could not extract it except for the tip of his ear, where it adhered to its wood: and it was a large arrow of the arrows of the Turks, with soft iron, in which there are no ear-holes.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	The Jew therefore recovered, and there was no bad accident to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arabic arrow, and that one has ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	So I tied a knot around it between two threads; and it was already submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	So delicate was I when I drew it out, that it bled profusely; and the man recovered.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I took out another arrow from the belly of the man who had fallen; and we were thinking that he would die of it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After that, he remained with us for thirty days, and there was no change in him regarding his condition, so I tied a knot around the arrow; and I cut it off from him, and he recovered, and nothing bad happened to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man who had an arrow in his back, and the wound was healed over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After that, he was out of bed after seven years, and the arrow had come out from the root of his thigh.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman who had an arrow in her belly, and the wound was healed over it, and the arrow remained inside her; nor did she have any change regarding her condition, and this woman didn't notice any harm in any of her natural functions.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man, to whom an arrow had fallen on the face; and the wound was healed over it, and remained there, causing him no great pain; and similar things were many.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I took out an arrow from the prince of the king, which had fallen into his nose, and had already fallen towards the right side a little; and the arrow was completely concealed.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	So I was called to heal him after the loss of the arrow for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	Then I found the arrow's shaft tightly bound.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	So I asked him what it felt like, and he didn't feel it either; but himself felt the prick and the pain on his right side.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hoped that was where the prick came from.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	So I applied a plaster to the place where the power of attraction and digestion came from, trusting myself that the place would heal; and it appeared to me a sign of the arrow, so that I could tie it up: and nothing happened in that place indicating that the arrow was still there.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	Therefore be diligent with the plaster on it for many days; and there was no accident, and the break mended in the meantime; and he remained weak from the removal of it for some space of time, until one day he felt a bowstring in his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	So I put a sharp medicine on the break, and tried it after many days, until I felt a slight pain of the bowstring sticking to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added more of the sharp medicine to the opening of the wound, until we could see the end of the bowstring clearly; and it passed by me with that space of time of about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the swelling of the wound had lessened, and it was possible for me to stick my finger into it, and move it, and not come out: then I did not cease to be diligent, and thought up means with which to deal with it, until one day I stuck it in with bent fingers, according to the form of their ends, so that I drew it out.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the break.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And some doctors say that the nose cartilage is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I restored it, and the break mended, and the injury was healed completely in health: and he did not hurt him at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of the extraction of some bowstrings: so that you put that rule and sign on it which I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For the parts of this art and their distinctions are not understood when they are told: nor does that book understand, and the skilled craftsman compares little with much: and he finds a new operation and a new instrument for going down things which are outside the scope of this art when they happen.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say then, that bowstrings do not come out of the member from which they are fixed, unless by two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	He entered through a door from which he was attracted.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by another part on the opposite side.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which had exited from where he entered, or is a projectile proceeding in fleshly place: and it is attracted, and it exits.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	That if it does not obey to exit at the time in which it falls: then it is necessary that you should let go of that for a few days, until it putrefies the flesh which is in circumambiention of it: and the attraction of it shall be alleviated, and its exit.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And also if it is figured in a bone, and does not obey to you to exit, then you should let go of that also for a few days: and repeatedly make it with the attraction and movement every day, until it exits.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	That if it does not obey to you to exit after days, then it is necessary that you should perform in circumambiention of the projectile in that bone with a sharp material from all parts until it increases.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract it, and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If however the projectile is fixed in a bone of the head, and has already proceeded in one ventrum cerebri, and appears from an accident of those which I mentioned: then abstain from attracting the projectile, and let go of it, until it becomes equated to be in its place after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the projectile reaches to the soft part, then death does not prolong for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the projectile is not fixed, unless it penetrates to the soft part only through a bone's body, and remains for a few days, and nothing happens to him from those accidents: then you should use your devices in attracting the projectile and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If however it is fixed tightly, and does not obey to you to attract: then administer sharp devices in circumambiention of the projectile, like a needle: then take care of the place, until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If however the projectile has already gone out from its place in the body, and is concealed and hidden from your sense: then seek it out.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then draw it with some instruments suitable for drawing.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If you cannot stretch it out above the bone because of the constriction of the skin, and its length in the deep: and there is no bone, nor nerve, nor vein: then find on it till the tendon thickens and becomes able to be pulled out the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If it has ears that can hold the hook, then free the meat from within them with all your skill and effort: and if you cannot remove the meat from the break in the ears, and their twist, till it heeds.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And you, whenever you are extracting the arrow, whatever part it is in, then use your twisted hand with forceps to all parts, till you make it heede: and the finest of things, so that the arrow does not break, and makes it difficult for you to attract it, and its extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot take hold of it in one hour, then leave it for a few days, till what is around it rotten.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then try again: for if the flow of blood annoys you, then administer what we said in our book on curing: and guard your skill from cutting into bone, or nerve, or tendon.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer skill in every way that is possible for you to remove the arrow: and let it be with ease, and quietness, or slowness, and strength, as I told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it should be, that when you are drawing the arrow out, so that it is bent according to its shape, according to what it was like at the time of the break of the arrow in itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Since it is more careful.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If you cannot do that to it, then administer what is possible for you in shapes.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	But the arrow which is coming out of the opposite part, or has already come out a little to the outside: or makes the end of the arrow go up by sensation from the upper part of the skin nearby, and you see it rising: so cut off over it, and let the section be according to the quantity that the forceps hold in it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then attract him: for it is easy to bring about death.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	But if it is retained in the bone, then twist your hand according to the roundness, until the Arrow prints on the bone, and amplifies itself: then pull it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: let it go for a few days: then repeat it, until it leaves.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	That if the Arrow is in it, then push it with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	But if it has fallen, and you administer a push: then introduce the sharp tool into it, so that its sharpness enters at the end of the Arrow: then push it with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	But if the Arrow is sharp, then push it with the instrument that enters into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	For the Arrow glides through it.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	That if the Arrow is poisoned, then let him make a sharp flesh, in which there is poison: if you can do that.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then take care of it with him when it comes to that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	That if the Arrow is falling in the chest, or in the belly, or in the vein, and is close to that which you touch by trying, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut, and guard against the incision of the vein, or nerve, and remove it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound, if you see it, and guard that, until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of the pincers, with which the Arrows are removed.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	The ends should be similar to the ear, which have been made like irons: when they grasp on to the Arrow, they do not let go of it.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And they are made in various shapes, large and small, and medium, according to the length of the Arrow, and its thickness, and the constriction of the wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	Form of the Pincer.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And form of the Pincer is deaf.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the extremities of the radius as regards the entrance into the arrowhead and it is forced with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	This extremities, when impelling concauld, are concauld like the feather of a bird: that is to say, the entrance into the arrowhead and its impulsion.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On venesection of veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter LVII. On venesection of veins.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The venesections, of which there is a tradition in the body, are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	From which in the head are sixteen: two pulsating veins, which are behind the ears, called two herbs; and two arteries, which are appearing in two temporals; and two veins, which are in the two tear ducts of the two eyes, called two aspics; and a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead; and a vein that is at the end of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two jugulars, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins, which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins, which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are called Algecilla.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins, which are under the tongue.
